title: Dalla filologia digitale alla filologia computazionale
text:
La filologia digitale sta vivendo una nuova rivoluzione, alimentata dalla larga disponibilità e democratizzazioni di metodi di apprendimento automatico e di intelligenza artificiale di tipo generativo. Questa nuova rivoluzione arriva in un momento in cui la comunità scientifica non ha ancora metabolizzato la filologia digitale basata sulla rappresentazione del testo nello spazio digitale. Diventa quindi urgente per la comunità di comprendere le sfide e le implicazioni di questo nuova realtà per evitare da un lato di restare ai margini degli ultimi sviluppi tecnologici, dall’altro di cedere ai facili entusiasmi che tendono a minimizzare i problemi epistemologici ed etici di queste tecnologie. Il ciclo di lezioni vuole quindi partire da un inquadramento storico e metodologico della filologia digitale, per presentare poi le nuove tecnologie e i recenti sviluppi nelle discipline che riguardano testi e documenti. Questa presentazione si servirà del caso studio di una ricerca in corso sui manoscritti moderni (1575-1800).

Calendario degli incontri

  • 17 Febbraio, ore 17-19. “Ieri oggi e domani delle edizioni digitali”. La lezione fornisce un inquadramento storico e metodologico.
  • 18 Febbraio, ore 17-19. “Scienze del testo e del documento e metodi computazionali: paleografia, codicologia, papirologia e filologia”. La lezione presenta le ultime novità nelle varie discipline che studiano il testo e le sue materialità.
  • 20 Febbraio, ore 11-13. “Manoscritti moderni e metodi computazionali”. La lezione presenta i problemi posti per lo studio dei manoscritti moderni, e i metodi scelti dal progetto di ricerca “PRIMA” per rispondere a questi problemi.
  • 21 Febbraio, ore 11-13. “Filologia strutturale e filologia quantitativa per la testualità fluida”. La lezione presenta un nuovo metodo filologico computazionale elaborato per gestire la testualità fluida dei testi trasmessi dai manoscritti moderni, ma anche per le larghe tradizioni caratterizzate da una forte diffrazione e contaminazione.
place: Dipartimento di Filologia Classica e Italianistica (FICLIT)
subtitle: Ciclo di distinguished lectures a cura della Prof.ssa Elena Pierazzo (Università di Tours)

title: Revealing Connections
text:
The Revealing Connections: Leveraging Linked Open Data to discover knowledge through ResearchSpace is a one-day seminar dedicated to the topics relevant for (but not limited to) better understanding the complex world of digital semantic archives. The seminar will offer insights into the ever-growing field of Linked Open Data and Semantic Web technologies, while also providing some concrete examples in form of methods and tools useful for creating digital collections.

Speakers invited to attend and share with our audience their knowledge, pluriennial experience and best practices, are confirmed experts of their fields, and their contributions are thought to serve as guidance for present and future works of students, professionals, institutions and research community in general.

The first part of the seminar will be entirely dedicated to ResearchSpace, a free open-source semantic web platform supporting knowledge preservation and diversity. The audience will be presented with this innovative system from both theoretic and practical points of view. Afterwards, during the second part of the seminar, our speakers will dedicate their lectures to Semantic Web and Linked Open Data, presenting the state of the art and the latest tendencies in these fields. Finally, the two concluding talks will be characterised by the intersections with the Chinese cultural heritage, as a tribute to two projects directly related to this seminar.

This seminar is being organised as a part of the Framework for Attracting and Strengthening Research Excellence (FARE) funded project entitled WenDAng - WRITE Digital Archive (CINECA code: R20K7ZB983), directly related to the European Research Council (ERC) funded project entitled WRITE - New Forms of Calligraphy in China: A Contemporary Cultural Mirror (GA n. 949645), in collaboration with the /DH.arc - Digital Humanities Research Center of the University of Bologna. The dissemination of knowledge that will occur during this seminar will also highly contribute to the WenDAng project objectives and goals, especially for the data modelling process and the construction of the technological infrastracture that will support the preservation, visualisation and dissemination of the research data through the WRITE Digital Semantic Archive.
place_extended: Giorgio Prodi Lecture HallPiazza, San Giovanni in Monte 2, Bologna
subtitle: Leveraging Linked Open Data to Discover Knowledge through Research Space

title: Nuove macchine e antichi saperi: IA, Supercalcolo e dati per il patrimonio culturale
text:
Una giornata di approfondimento dedicata all’uso dell’Intelligenza Artificiale, del supercalcolo e dei big data per valorizzare il patrimonio culturale, dalle biblioteche alle opere d’arte, dai siti archeologici alle pellicole cinematografiche.

Partecipa per scoprire come le tecnologie avanzate stanno rivoluzionando le discipline umanistiche e creando nuove modalità di fruizione e conoscenza.

L’evento si svolgerà in modalità ibrida. Per partecipare è necessario iscriversi attraverso l'apposito form.

Programma

  • ORE 9:15
    Accoglienza
  • ORE 9:30
    Introduzione ai lavori del convegno
    Modera Eleonora Barelli, Project manager IFAB
  • ORE 9.45
    “Intelligenza artificiale e società: immagini, percezioni, fraintendimenti”
    Prof. Massimiano Bucchi
  • ORE 10:10
    “Discipline umanistiche: digitali, intelligenti, estese”
    Prof. Aldo Gangemi
  • ORE 10:35
    “I Linked Open Data e la nuova identità dei cataloghi”
    Prof.ssa Francesca Tomasi
  • ORE 11:00
    “Intelligenza Artificiale e manoscritti: implicazioni filologico-linguistiche”
    Prof. Gennaro Ferrante
  • ORE 11:20
    “Intelligenza Artificiale e manoscritti: implicazioni paleografico-codicologiche”
    Dott. Riccardo Montalto
  • ORE 11:40
    “Le sfide dell’Intelligenza Artificiale alla creazione artistica e al diritto d’autore”
    Dott.ssa Caterina Del Federico
  • ORE 12:05
    Presentazioni di casi d’uso: Il Mulino • CINECA • Visiva Lab
    Modera Laura Mortini (EuroCC Italy)
  • ORE 13:00
    Conclusioni
place_extended: Biblioteca del Mulino, Vicolo Posterla 1, Bologna
subtitle: Convegno di studi e casi concreti per l'innovazione

title: DH after graduation
text:
A meeting to introduce different scenarios and possibilities for DHDK graduates and to show them the realities interested in involving digital humanists, and thus where DHDK graduates can offer their expertise.

Programme:

  • 15:00-15:20
    Welcoming and introduction
  • 15:20-16:20
    Working on DH after graduation
  • 16:20-16:50
    Q&A session
  • 16:50-17:00
    Q&A session

Sessions & speakers:

  • PhD in DH
    Francesca Tomasi, Director of the PhD on Cultural Heritage in the Digital Ecosystem
  • Cultural Heritage institution
    Chiara Storti, Librarian at the Biblioteca Centrale Nazionale di Firenze
  • Company working in the Cultural Heritage domain
    Federico Borreani, Responsible for Analysis and Strategy at BAM! Cultural Strategies

This event is mainly for DHDK second-year students, but it is also open to all interested DHDK students.

Participants are kindly asked to prepare their questions in advance to facilitate the Q&A session.
subtitle: A meeting to introduce different scenarios and possibilities for DHDK graduates

title: Elena Giglia, “Open science: in dialogue with society”
text:
We shall explore the two-way connection among science and society - as Open Science is not just "sharing" at the end of the process, it's a different way of creating knowledge starting from the beginning, and possibly co-creating it. After discussing the potentiality of citizen science, we shall delve into the realm of science communication with a focus on science for policy, for a truly evidence-informed policy making.

Elena Giglia, PhD, Masters' Degree in Librarianship and Masters' Degree in Public Institutions Management, is Head of the Open Science Unit at the University of Turin. She has been part of the European Open Science network for many years, attending national and international conferences, and writing and lecturing on Open Access and Open Science. She was a member (2019-2020) of the Committee on Open Science at the Ministry for University and Research (MUR). She actively collaborates with the ICDI - Italian Computer and Data Infrastructure Competence center on Open Science, EOSC and FAIR data and with several national and international projects. She represents OPERAS Research Infrastructure in the EOSC Association. She serves in several Scientific Committees and Advisory Boards.
subtitle: Final seminar of the "Open Science" course, Digital Humanities and Digital Knowledge (DHDK)

title: Datathon Wikidata
text:
Appuntamento a lunedì 13 maggio 2024 per un Datathlon Wikidata, una maratona di acquisizione dati che si terrà nell’Aula Affreschi (via Zamboni 34, Bologna), dalle 09:00 alle 19:00, con pausa pranzo intermedia.

Il datathon, organizzato da Francesca Tomasi (UniBo), Valentina Pasqual (UniBo), Camillo Carlo Pellizzari di San Girolamo (SNS), Matteo Romanello (UNIL), e Federico Boschetti (CNR-ILC/VeDPH) mira alla creazione di nuovi elementi Wikidata (si prevede nell'ordine di alcune centinaia) relativi in particolare a dati di natura bibliografica sul tema del falso documentario. Questa iniziativa ha lo scopo di espandere il grafo Wikidata rendendolo sempre più utile per gli studi umanistici.

L’unico pre-requisito per la partecipazione al Datathon è la consultazione di un tutorial online (pre-registrato) di 90 minuti di introduzione a Wikidata, alla modifica dei suoi contentuti e all'inserimento di metadati bibliografici. Il video è reperibile al seguente indirizzo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2UDrn-HzO68.

Chi è interessato è pregato di mandare una manifestazione di interesse inviando una mail all’indirizzo boldh@unibo.it entro il 30 aprile, indicando come oggetto: "Manifestazione d’interesse per Datathon Wikidata" e scrivendo nel corpo della mail: nome, cognome.

Il progetto rientra tra le attività del Gruppo Wikidata per Musei, Archivi e Biblioteche. Per partecipare è necessario creare un account Wikidata (o verificare di possedere già un account del mondo WikiMedia) entro l'8 maggio 2024.
Per inserire dati su Wikidata è necessario infatti avere un account attivo da almeno 4 giorni.

Dopo aver creato l’account, è caldamente consigliato di cominciare a familiarizzare con la piattaforma, procedendo alla personalizzazione delle impostazioni al fine dello svolgimento delle attività del 13 maggio 2024, seguendo:

  • Istruzioni
  • Videotutorial
subtitle: Maratona di acquisizione dati di natura bibliografica sul tema del falso documentario

title: Charles van den Heuvel, A classification of the arts in a digital ecosystem. Exploring Dynamic ODP’s
text:
Charles van den Heuvel studied Art History at the University of Groningen and gained his PhD in 1991 with a thesis on the introduction of Italian urban planning and fortification in the Netherlands (1540-1609). After his study he worked in various cultural heritage institutions, universities and research institutions.

From January 2011 till December 2022, Van den Heuvel was head of the research group of history of knowledge, now known as Knowledge and Art Practices. Furthermore, he is an emeritus professor at the University of Amsterdam holding the chair: “Digital Methods and Historical Disciplines, especially the History of Knowledge and Information Science”. He was the p.i. of the following projects:

  • NWO Large Investment Grant: Golden Agents: Creative Industries and the Making of the Dutch Golden Age. (2017-2022)
  • NWO Smart Culture – Big Data/Digital Humanities: Virtual Interiors as Interfaces for Big Historical Data (2018-2022)
  • NWO/NWA science communication [only in Dutch]: Door de lens van Antoni/[Through the lens of Antoni] (2022)
  • KNAW Public-Private Cooperation-Digital Humanities: Mapping Notes and Nodes in Networks: Exploring potential relationships in biographical data and cultural networks in the creative industry in Amsterdam and Rome in the Early Modern Period (2014)
  • KNAW Public-Private Cooperation-Digital Humanities: Dynamic Drawings in Enhanced Publications (2012-2013)

Furthermore, he was the co-applicant and leader on behalf of the Huygens Institute in the consortium of the NWO- Middle Large Investment project:

  • Circulation of Knowledge and Learned Practices in the 17th Century Dutch Republic/ePistolarium

Since his retirement in December 2022, he is a guest employee at the Huygens Institute, a research institute of the "Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences (KNAW)" in Amsterdam,  and in particular he works in the departments Data Management and Knowledge & Art Practices in which context he will continue his research directed toward the application of digital resources and methods in the Humanities.
place_extended: Aula Guglielmi, Ground Floor, Via Zamboni 32, Bologna
subtitle: Lecture conducted as part of the Cultural Heritage in the Digital Ecosystem PhD programme

title: Patrimonio culturale e infrastrutture di ricerca: la conservazione e la comunicazione al pubblico
text:
Building on the experience of the European project (H2020) Una.Resin, where methodologies and tools for creating research and innovation ecosystems in transnational research networks were developed, the aim is to analyze the impact of digital transformation and the interconnection of data and interdependent ecosystems on the preservation and communication of cultural heritage.

The inquiry will explore how digital research infrastructures interact with cultural heritage, as well as with the data aggregations and digital assets of libraries, archives, and museums. The scope extends beyond the materials of university libraries and museums, delving into the galaxy of research initiatives and materials preserved by both university and non-university institutions made available through specific thematic/disciplinary projects.

The purpose of this reflection is to initiate a dialogue on forms of cultural heritage sharing that are compatible and interoperable with research infrastructures, fostering fruitful exchanges between cultural institutions and heritage communities with scientific research institutions. This transition into digital infrastructures carries with it a complex experience and activity of integrating semantic relationships from diverse scientific and educational fields preceding the digital era.

Discussions will revolve around how universities can facilitate the valorization of cultural heritage through digital research infrastructures, not only limited to their own heritage but also stimulating interoperability with other local and international initiatives. It will encourage synergies on common interests such as long-term preservation, innovative forms of participation, citizen science, storytelling, open licenses, etc.

Further reflections will focus on the flexibility of conceptual models for integrating content and metadata, ensuring the potential for interaction with digital research infrastructures structured internationally across various disciplinary domains. This includes the development of new ways to share delivery data and the provision of services, especially in Knowledge Discovery.
place_extended: Sala VIII Centenario, Rettorato, Via Zamboni 33, Bologna
subtitle: Sharing experiences and perspectives on the enhancement of cultural heritage within digital research infrastructures."
